Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of the day pressing on my shoulders. The salon was nearly empty, but Mrs. Carter’s voice echoed off the mirrors as she berated the unevenness of her bangs. I tried to soothe her, apologizing and offering to fix it, all while keeping my tone calm and professional. My mind, though, kept drifting to the row of trash bins outside my apartment building. Tomorrow was pickup day, and I knew my neighbor, Mr. Lee, always expected everyone to wait until the bins were full before dragging them to the curb. They were only half-full tonight, but I had a bag of hair clippings and salon waste that needed to go out. If I waited, the salon would smell, but if I took the trash out now, I’d risk Mr. Lee’s disapproving glare and a possible note on my door about “shared responsibility.” Mrs. Carter’s complaints grew louder, demanding my full attention, but my thoughts tugged in two directions—toward the expectations of a good neighbor and the demands of a professional hairdresser. My heart pounded as I realized I couldn’t satisfy both at once.
